meanings.def: to move your head or the top half of your body forwards and downwards as a sign of respect or to say hello or goodbye
examples: bow (to/before somebody/something) He bowed low to the assembled crowd.
bow down (to/before somebody/something) The people all bowed down before the emperor.
He swept off his hat and bowed deeply to the queen.
The emperor's subjects bowed down before him.
The pianist stood up and bowed to the audience.

meanings.def: to move your head forwards and downwards
examples: She bowed her head in shame.
They stood in silence with their heads bowed.

meanings.def: to bend or make something bend
examples: (+ adv./prep) The pines bowed in the wind.
bow something (+ adv./prep) Their backs were bowed under the weight of their packs.

meanings.def: to be too polite to an important person in order to gain their approval
examples: She was beginning to tire of all their bowing and scraping.

idioms.def: to be too polite to an important person in order to gain their approval
examples: She was beginning to tire of all their bowing and scraping.

meanings.def: the act of bending your head or the upper part of your body forward in order to say hello or goodbye to somebody or to show respect
examples: She gave a slight bow of her head in greeting.
The messenger made a formal bow and left the room.
He gave a formal bow and left the room.
He made a deep bow to the king.
He gave her a deep bow.

meanings.def: the front part of a boat or ship
examples: A huge whale crossed our bows.
We left two men in the bow to receive the cargo.
There's a small boat on the port bow.
The ship's name was printed on her bow.
There were huge waves breaking over the bows.
They fired a shot across our bow/​bows.

meanings.def: something that you say or do as a warning to somebody about what might happen if they do not change, etc.
to bow to the audience as they are applauding you
examples: She came back on stage to take another bow.
The song ended and Albert took a bow.
(figurative) The boss takes his final bow today.
(figurative) The team's chairman takes his final bow at this match.

idioms.def: something that you say or do as a warning to somebody about what might happen if they do not change, etc.
to bow to the audience as they are applauding you
examples: She came back on stage to take another bow.
The song ended and Albert took a bow.
(figurative) The boss takes his final bow today.
(figurative) The team's chairman takes his final bow at this match.

meanings.def: a weapon used for shooting arrows, consisting of a long curved piece of wood or metal with a tight string joining its ends
examples: He was armed with a bow and arrow.
She drew and aimed her bow.

meanings.def: a knot with two loops and two loose ends which is used for decoration on clothes, in hair, etc. or for tying shoes
examples: to tie your shoelaces in a bow
Her hair was tied back in a neat bow.
a dress decorated with bows and ribbons
Can you tie a bow?
She tied the ribbon into a neat bow.

meanings.def: a long thin piece of wood with thin string stretched along it, used for playing musical instruments such as the violin
examples: She drew the bow across the strings.

meanings.def: to have more than one skill or plan that you can use if you need to
examples: The exhibition shows that he has other strings to his artistic bow.

idioms.idiom: have another string/more strings to your bow
idioms.def: to have more than one skill or plan that you can use if you need to
examples: The exhibition shows that he has other strings to his artistic bow.

meanings.def: to use a bow to play a musical instrument that has strings
